segments.text: All right, sir.
And the next question, could you talk more about your views on the enemy?
Well, surely.
I did not hate the North Vietnamese.
I remember when I first came into the Marine Corps, the first argument I had, I despised the Japanese.
His brother had been a Marine in the Second World War and had been killed.
And he hated the Japanese as a race.
I didn't feel that hatred toward North Vietnamese.
I knew that they were the opponents, the enemy, or the aggressors.
And I had a job to do to go out there and fight and win.
But I never
got into a position or a situation which caused me to hate them as a race or as a foreign country.
I didn't like them as a foreign country.
Propaganda against them was such that they were the aggressors.
They were trying to take over another country.
I think most Americans, and I am surely one, who supported underdogs.
and like to support a cause like that.
So from that aspect, I thought the North Vietnamese were wrong in trying to go down and take over South Vietnam.
I didn't agree with the way the North Vietnamese lived.
In other words, they did not have a democracy.
South Vietnam had a democracy, although there was a lot of corruption that goes on.
There's corruption everywhere.
But by and large, I think they had a democracy.

I also believe in the domino theory that if Vietnam fell, then other countries around them would fall, finally until you get down to Malaysia and to the Malaccan Straits and cut off shipping halfway around the world at that point.
And we're seeing that to some degree now.
There's not a timetable for the domino period.
But Cambodia is gone.
Thailand's in trouble.
Laos is in trouble.
So we've just seen the domino effect of the country starting to fall there on the realm of Asia.
All right, sir.
Concerning the...
if you will, the individualism of the war, the one-year tours.

Do you believe that, or could you just talk about that, concerning having the one-year tours versus having units go over to a war together, doing whatever they're going to, whatever operations, and then coming back as a unit?
Okay.
Versus going over and staying over also, or just rotating people as opposed to units.
Yes, sir.
I don't know of a better way, another way to make it work other than rotating people.
Ideally, in a perfect world, we would like to have a combat unit that's had all of its people in there.
for a reasonable length of time so that that unit is well trained.
You can pick it up, send it to a combat zone, and fight.
And then at the end of its assigned tour, you can pick them up, take another unit, and put them there in their place to continue the war effort.
You have several problems, and they're massive problems.
First of all, when you take a unit and plop it into a country like that,
into a war zone, probably inexperienced in the nature of that particular war.
And it takes them a while to come up to speed.
For instance, we brought a regiment, put together a regiment in Vietnam, and brought them in.
We created a regiment of 27 Marines in California and brought them over to Vietnam.
and they were to take over a certain sector in the 1st Marine Division Zone of Action.

There was so much apprehension at the senior command level about their survivability that they had a two- or three-week training period with the 1st Marine Division units that were in there to learn about the booby traps, to learn how to fight in the jungle and to eat.
And they took a lot of casualties after they first got there.
After they were cut loose, we actually had people nearly holding their hands for two or three weeks.
And when that development part was cut loose, they suffered high casualties until they became combat savvy.
The next problem is that when you have a war and you're expanding your forces,
First of all, you're having casualties of the units in the combat zone, and you've got to replace those at the same time to be trying to build these new units and then get them trained.
I'll tell you, it takes a long time to train a combat unit.
And if you're starting with all fresh people with no corporate knowledge, then that's extremely difficult.
And your personnel flow, your manpower flow, just barely prevents you from creating new units
maybe 50% combat veterans and the rest inexperienced soldiers and sending them off to combat.
On the other hand, the individual rotation is difficult because you never have a combat organization that is a well-trained, well-oiled machine.
You've got people coming in weekly.
effectiveness is down to that lowest common denominator, that new person, until he gets some experience and some training.
On the other hand, it's better for, let's say, an infantry company that might have 150 people
It's far better to have only 10 or 15 of those that are in the training process and are in experience.
That's 10% as opposed to a big unit, 100% in experience.
That's where you can have a lot of serious mistakes and have a lot of casualties.
I would have preferred to go over with a unit that was full strength
And all of its equipment, people were well trained.
But I think that will only work if you first go into a combat.
After that, the follow-on units are just too hard to put together.
In the ideal situation, if everything were perfect, if you had everything that you needed, that would be a great way to go to war.
You would know all the people.
You would know how dependable the man on your right is, the man on your left is.
Practice.
All right, sir.
Did you notice any differences?
I guess first, if you could talk some more about your experience in Vietnam in 1963 when you first went there doing the hydro surveys.
Did you have any contact with the enemy or anything other than just doing the hydro surveys?
We had contact with the enemy on several occasions.
As I say, the war had been going on in Vietnam for a long time.
We got ambushed a couple of times.
We were not on seek and destroy missions.
We were strictly doing reconnaissance missions.
But we got ambushed a couple of times, got pinned down in as much as eight hours.
So there was a full-fledged war going on.
It was a war between the North Vietnamese and the South Vietnamese.
We just happened to get in the way a couple of times.
And did you see any differences in the way, I guess in the overall context, the way the war was being fought in 63 versus 68?
I really can't comment on that because I wasn't in there in a position to have first-hand knowledge of that.
Ours were all meeting engagements where we walked into something, got in the middle of something,
We operated off the ship every night.
We'd go in in the morning and come out at night.
So I was not there permanently.
We did not have an opportunity to observe it through our system.
All right, sir.
Do you have any experience with the Marine PAC units or the program, the pacification?
PAC or the CAP units, Combat Action Detentions?
Yes, sir, the CAP units.
We had some, and I think it was a very successful program.
What we did was take Marines.
We would set up a command organization or a command structure, and we would take a squad of Marines and put them in a village.
And then they were there to teach the people how to defend themselves.
They would dig fighting holes and trenches around their village.
They would set up a reaction force to respond to critical areas.
They had weapons.
We taught them how to clean their weapons, how to fire them.
and gave them the basic combat skills you need for defensive type warfare.
It was also a good source of intelligence.
We had, and it was really, it resulted in pacifying the various areas and it was very effective until we had to pull those organizations out.
A lot of those squads or platoons that were involved in the combat action platoons,
Got in some good scraps, good combat.
The North Vietnamese or the Viet Cong learned how effective they were, and they went up on the hit list.
Usually the intelligence was good enough that they could be reinforced and protected.
Occasionally it was not, and we did not have an entire squad, but it was a very effective program.
It was a dedicated bunch of Marines that were involved in that.

And if you don't have enough military forces to actively patrol and cover an area, then I can't think of a better way to do it than to leave just little pockets of people in each one of the villages to bolster the local defenses there that those villages had and create a reporting chain where we could gather intelligence.
All right, sir.
And your views on the anti-war demonstrators?
Didn't have any in Vietnam.
You have to say back here in the States.
Of course, I was going to graduate school after that, so I really wasn't particularly attuned to it.
I'm trying to think back as to what my views were at that time.
I thought they were un-American to start with.
They were a country unified.
that you ought to or ought to support the fight.
And I guess that was my first awakening that how great the same could be.
It's not popular, that people would rise up in arms against it.
I think it's one thing to protest.
It's another to be destructive, where they burned ROTC buildings on campuses.
where they burned the flags and the draft boards.
I recognize these are acts of symbolism.
But to me, that's carrying it too far.
When you carry it to the length that you appear to be anti-American, that's too far.
I think Jane Fonda was wrong in going to the North Vietnamese
Yes, sir.
Your views on the Selective Service, the National Guard?
Well, some people have
had the view that there was such a waiting list to get into, say, like the National Guard because they would stay out of combat.

And on the Selective Service, the draft, given the nature of Vietnam and the presidents that they deceived the American public and that they were pumping in Americans over to Vietnam through the use of the draft.
Well, first of all, I believe in conscription.
I think every American ought to serve his country, whether it's peacetime or war.
I think that's been one of the strengths of this country.
One of the problems that we are facing now and will become greater in the future is the fact that our politicians and our Congressmen lack military experience.
a large portion of it goes to national defense.
You can't have a strong country without a strong national defense.

And we're getting to the point where the majority of congressmen have not served in the military, have not gained an appreciation and an understanding of what the militaries all have and what its roles and missions are.
So from that point of view, I think conscription is good.
as to whether or not it was effective during, whether the Selective Service was effective during Vietnam.
In all, during all conflicts, you have exceptions to all rules.
Waivers are given.
This is where politics comes in, sprains are pulled.
I'll get my son out of going, I think, into law school or into medical school or into college when he shouldn't be flying around.
The system is designed for things like that.
What the system is not designed for is professors giving people passing grades when they're funded, and that went on to a large extent.

If you could get into college and you were at a liberal campus with good profs, you got grades, not necessarily an education, because those profs didn't support the war effort, and that was one person.
If they could pass someone, though they may not have deserved it, there was one less person that could go support that war and support the country.
I have no problem with the National Guard.
They've only got so many openings to fill.
The National Guard was not a problem.
I don't think their ranks swole at all.
You're always limited by a table of organization.
If someone gets out, you can replace that person.
I don't think the National Guard was a problem.
Talk about Dan Quayle being able to get into the National Guard.
I don't think a special opening was made for him.
There were some openings that he was able to get into.
All right, sir.

Concerning the reserves, though, I don't know what the thrust of that question is, but I do know that a lot of active reserve units or people in active reserve units were disappointed that they were not called to war, not activated and ordered to war.
When the President did not call up the reserves, a lot of those people left their reserve units and re-enlisted or came into the active Marine Corps to combat.
All right, sir.
You had said earlier that you had reopened Khe Sanh.
Could you comment on that and also any particular feelings of reopening something that had once been occupied
But, you know, it was giving, if you will, back to the enemy, but, like I say, going back to reopen it.
No, no particular feelings.
That was just another combat operation.
It was a large one.
To me, there was no emotional attachment to it or any symbolism to the fact that we'd occupied it.
We lost a lot of people there.
It was another objective of the combat operation.
It was just another operation for me.
It had some historical significance, but nothing other than that.
All right, sir.
Also, the last question, I guess it's a doozy, but your feelings of if and or how we could have won, or if you believe we did win.
Militarily, we won the war.
We won over there.
We were controlling the countryside.
through combat actions and then the fact that we were able to turn it over to pacification units.
We had done our job in military.
We did not win the war, though, because the country didn't support them.
That's the difference.
War is just one of those tools that politicians use in dealing with other countries.
when we couldn't escalate anymore.
And that was a political decision, not a military decision.
We've served our purpose.
We could have spent many more years there as an occupation force.
That would have given the Vietnamese more time to stabilize and build their country.
But they would have come to rely on us much more, because there's a lot of money that's spent on the military forces in there.
You've got a lot of people in there.
You're spending money.
You're buying goods.
You're building things.
And I think we would have caused the Vietnamese to become dependent on us if we had stayed in there too long.
But when we pulled out of Vietnam, we pulled out, I think, rather abruptly.
We should have come out more slowly.
probably made greater efforts to bolster the Vietnamese forces so that they could defend themselves and fight.
But we've reached a point in America's history where there was zero sentiment for that part of the world and no support.
And when the politicians cut off the first trains, you can't find them, so we had to pull out.
That's what happened right there.
There was a lack of support from the United States

I'm of the school of thought that unless we get into the only war that we will be able to successfully fight, and be careful in how I say that, the only war that will have popular U.S. support will be a world war.
Anything less than that will not.
We have to commit forces to a combat zone.
We need to go in there with sufficient forces to win within 30 days and be out within 90 days.
Americans, as I indicated earlier, like to go in, get the job done, wipe their hands, and get out.
And about a 90-day weather is all that allows.
So we have to pick where we're going if we have to go anywhere.
Go in there and actually do the job in 90 days and take the next 60 days to get out and guard the location.
After 90, I think we will see support of Americans waning, beginning to wane at 30 days.
And at 90 days, it will be on a rapid decline where we are.
And from that point on, we will not be able to fight a successful war.
The only exception to that would be if we were attacked in the case of a world war where we have
mobilization where everyone is involved, everyone's life is touched, then you may have the ideal support of most people, not all people.
That's the only exception.
That's a sad commentary, but that's the way Americans are made up.
We're industrious.
And that's why we like, because we're an industrial nation, we like to see things happen quickly.
You see it in business, you see it in how we conduct our affairs.
You want to go in and talk to a lawyer and get your business done and get out.
You want to start a company, you want to make a lot of money, you just hate the routine daily grind.
And it reflects in the support of the war.
All right, sir.
Well, I appreciate you giving me this time for this interview, and that concludes the interview.
